articles.headline: In Bolivia, Untapped Bounty Meets Nationalism
articles.snippet: Bolivia will not easily surrender its massive reserve of lithium, the mineral needed to power electric vehicles.
articles.abstract: Bolivia will not easily surrender its massive reserve of lithium, the mineral needed to power electric vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: UYUNI, Bolivia  In the rush to build the next generation of hybrid or electric cars, a sobering fact confronts both automakers and governments seeking to lower their reliance on foreign oil: almost half of the world’s lithium, the mineral needed to power the vehicles, is found here in Bolivia  a country that may not be willing to surrender it so easily.

articles.headline: Macy’s Cuts Dividend and 7,000 Jobs
articles.snippet: The department store chain said the job cuts, which amount to about 4 percent of its work force, and other actions are aimed at lowering annual expenses by about $400 million.
articles.abstract: The department store chain said the job cuts, which amount to about 4 percent of its work force, and other actions are aimed at lowering annual expenses by about $400 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Macy’s, one of the nation’s largest department stores, said Monday that it would cut 7,000 jobs, or 4 percent of its work force, making it the latest retailer to streamline operations. The steps will save cash, but like other companies, Macy’s is also using the economic downturn as a moment to make broad changes.

articles.headline: Wall St., a Financial Epithet, Stirs Outrage
articles.snippet: As investment bankers adjust to a new role as targets of scorn, they aren’t expecting pity, or a sympathetic ear.
articles.abstract: As investment bankers adjust to a new role as targets of scorn, they aren’t expecting pity, or a sympathetic ear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monday was the last day of Iris Chau’s 11-year career at JPMorgan Chase and she says there’s a lot she’ll miss about the job, including her colleagues, her paycheck and her role managing a technical support team. But one thing she won’t miss about JPMorgan: telling people that she works there.

articles.headline: Small Payroll, but Big Woes on Insurance
articles.snippet: The recession has accelerated the pressure on small-business owners to cut employee health coverage.
articles.abstract: The recession has accelerated the pressure on small-business owners to cut employee health coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLAIRE, Tex.  When the bottom fell out of the automotive market last year, Amberly Allen’s fast-growing direct-mail firm hit a wall in a hurry.

articles.headline: Hearings to Address Medical Helicopter Safety
articles.snippet: Hoping to reduce medical helicopters’ poor safety record, the National Transportation Safety Board will begin four days of hearings in Washington.
articles.abstract: Hoping to reduce medical helicopters’ poor safety record, the National Transportation Safety Board will begin four days of hearings in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a medical helicopter crashed near Chicago in October, killing three adults and a baby, it was more than a tragedy. It was part of a trend.

articles.headline: Chrysler’s New Ally Takes a Pragmatic Approach
articles.snippet: Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of the Fiat Group, is blunt in assessing a prospective alliance with Chrysler.
articles.abstract: Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of the Fiat Group, is blunt in assessing a prospective alliance with Chrysler.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The last two times Chrysler was sold  to Daimler-Benz in 1998 and to Cerberus Capital Management in 2007  its new owners promised nothing less than a remarkable renaissance for the smallest of Detroit’s Big Three.

articles.headline: What if Watchdogs Got Bonuses?
articles.snippet: Financiers have a big incentive to outsmart the financial police. It is called a bonus. How can federal agencies compete?
articles.abstract: Financiers have a big incentive to outsmart the financial police. It is called a bonus. How can federal agencies compete?

articles.headline: Internet Money in Fiscal Plan: Wise or Waste?
articles.snippet: An item in the proposed stimulus package would spend billions to expand broadband Internet service to rural areas.
articles.abstract: An item in the proposed stimulus package would spend billions to expand broadband Internet service to rural areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  At first glance, perhaps no line item in the nearly $900 billion stimulus program under consideration on Capitol Hill would seem to offer a more perfect way to jump-start the economy than the billions pegged to expand broadband Internet service to rural and underserved areas.

articles.headline: Obama’s Pledge to Reform Ethics Faces an Early Test
articles.snippet: After vowing to usher in a new era of responsibility, President Obama has shown a willingness to compromise between campaign rhetoric and Washington’s realities.
articles.abstract: After vowing to usher in a new era of responsibility, President Obama has shown a willingness to compromise between campaign rhetoric and Washington’s realities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  During almost two years on the campaign trail, Barack Obama vowed to slay the demons of Washington, bar lobbyists from his administration and usher in what he would later call in his Inaugural Address a “new era of responsibility.” What he did not talk much about were the asterisks.

articles.headline: Angels Flee From Tech Start-Ups
articles.snippet: The optimistic financiers who give entrepreneurs their first cash infusion are cutting back, threatening the technology economy.
articles.abstract: The optimistic financiers who give entrepreneurs their first cash infusion are cutting back, threatening the technology economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Technology entrepreneurs are having a devil of a time finding angels.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Iran Launches Satellite in a Challenge for Obama
articles.snippet: The launching of Iran’s first domestically produced satellite came amid concerns about nuclear ambitions.
articles.abstract: The launching of Iran’s first domestically produced satellite came amid concerns about nuclear ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran has fired a satellite into orbit and a shot across the bow of American diplomacy.
articles.byline: By Nazila Fathi and William J. Broad
